sec.p: Review

Taxanes and taxoids of the genus
Taxus
– A comprehensive inventory of chemical diversity
B.Markus Lange * , Caleb F. Conner
Institute of Biological Chemistry and M.J. Murdock Metabolomics Laboratory, Washington State University, Pullman, WA, 99164-7411, USA
ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Taxane
Taxoid
Taxol
ABSTRACT

The pseudoalkaloid diterpene Taxol® (paclitaxel) emerged as a best-selling anti-cancer drug in the mid-1990s. The compound attracted considerable interest because of its unique mechanism to stabilize microtubules, thus reducing dynamicity and ultimately promoting mitotic arrest. Taxol was originally isolated from members of the genus
Taxus
. Over the last 50 years, close to 600 metabolites with taxane scaffolds were isolated from various
Taxus species
and their structures reported. The present review article provides an overview of the known chemical diversity of taxanes, with an emphasis on the functionalization of diterpene scaffolds. The implications of the occurrence of chemically diverse taxane metabolites for unraveling Taxol biosynthesis and enabling pathway engineering are discussed as well.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
The yew family ( Taxaceae ) consists of evergreen trees and shrubs that can be divided into six genera, which include
Amentotaxus
(4 species occurring mostly in China ),
Austrotaxus
(1 species found exclusively in New Caledonia , an island territory in the South Pacific),
Cephalotaxus
(6 species endemic to eastern Asia),
Pseudotaxus
(1 species occurring in southern China ),
Taxus
(number of species still a matter of debate; distribution across the northern hemisphere but mainly in North America, Europe and Southeast Asia), and
Torreya
(6 or 7 species native to East Asia and North America). The taxonomy of the genus
Taxus
has remained controversial, mostly due to the lack of diagnostic morphological characters and the high degree of similarity among species. For example, the Himalayan yew (
T. wallichiana Zucc.
) appears to have been referred to as
T. baccata
L. in some studies; similarly,
T. chinensis Rehd.
,
T. yunnanensis Cheng et L. K. Fu
and
T. mairei (Lemee and Lev.) Hu ex Liu
may have been used interchangeably by some authors (
;
;
;
;
). In the present work, we are not attempting to reevaluate such assignments and the taxonomic details given here are thus the same as those reported in the original papers. Yews are relatively slow growing but can reach substantial height ( 20 m ) and trunk circumference ( 5 m ), according to the United States National Register of Champion Trees (www.americanforests.org) ( Fig. 1A ).
Taxus
is thought to have descended from Paleotaxus rediviva , an extinct species preserved in

sec.title: 2. Chemical classification of taxanes
3. Group I: Taxanes with a 6/8/6 ring system
sec.p:
Metabolites with a 6/8/6 ring system (nomenclature based on number of carbons in the A, B and C rings) ( Table 1 ) constitute the most common class of taxanes, with 349 known structures occurring in the genus
Taxus
. They are biosynthetically derived directly from taxa-4 (20),11-diene and often referred to as normal taxanes. They can be further subdivided based on the functionalization of the taxane core, as detailed below.

sec.title:
4. Group II: 11(15 →
1) Abeo taxanes
sec.p:
Metabolites with a 5/7/
6 ring system (11(15→1) abeo taxanes) are an abundant class of taxanes, with 127 known structures reported for members of the genus Taxus ( Table 1 ). The first taxane of this class was observed in experiments where Taxol was treated with electrophilic reagents, which led to a mixture of products with opened oxetane ring and contracted A and B rings (
). It was later shown that such ring-contracted abeo taxanes are naturally occurring metabolites in Taxus species (
., 1993 b). The following paragraphs summarize the known chemical diversity in the context of functionalization patterns of the 11 ( 15 →1) abeo taxane core.

11. Taxane structural diversity in the context of
Taxus
taxonomy
sec.p:
The enormous chemical diversity of taxanes found in the genus
Taxus
begs the question if there are patterns for the occurrence of taxane classes across species. Before reporting on the results of a chemotaxonomic analysis, we need to briefly outline some of the challenges. Traditionally, the genus
Taxus
has included eight species based on their geographic distribution (
): (1)
T. baccata
L. - Europe, North Africa and Southwest Asia, (2)
T. cuspidata Siebold & Zucc.
- East Asia , (3)
T. wallichiana Zucc.
– Himalayan range, (4)
T. sumatrana (Miq.) de Laub.
- southern China , Philippines , Taiwan , Sunda Islands of Indonesia , (5)
T. globosa Schltdl.
– Central America and Mexico , (6)
T. brevifolia Nutt.
– Pacific Northwest of the United States , (7)
T. floridana Nutt. ex Chapm.
- West Florida , and (8)
T. canadensis Marshall
– central and eastern North America. Based on detailed morphological characters, the genus was later proposed to include 24 species and 55 varieties (
). However, morphological studies suffer from a relatively high level of phenotypic plasticity even within a species. A further complication results from the fact that hybridization among species has been confirmed (for example,
T. cuspidata
x
T. canadensis
= T. x hunnewelliana and
T. baccata
x
T. cuspidata
= T. x
media
) (
). Molecular phylogenetic analyses have not been entirely conclusive, but there appears to be an emerging consensus for the recognition of somewhere between nine and eleven species (
T. baccata , T. brevifolia , T. canadensis , T. chinensis
(to be included in
T. wallichiana
according to some authors),
T. cuspidata , T. floridana , T. fauna , T. globosa , T. mairei
(to be included in
T. wallichiana
according to some authors),
T. sumatrana and T. wallichiana
) (
;
;
;
). There has clearly been confusion in reporting taxane constituents, with the Himalayan yew being referred to as
T. baccata
ssp. wallichiana ,
T. wallichiana
,
T. fuana
, and
T. contorta
; likewise, the Chinese yew has been referred to as
T. yunnanensis
,
T. mairei
,
T. chinensis
,
T. wallichiana
, and
T. sumatrana ( Hao et al., 2015 )
. It is impossible to resolve potential issues resulting from inconsistent species naming in the body of literature on taxanes, which spans more than five decades, and we thus must rely on the designation used in the original publication.

Keeping these limitations in mind, we can ask about the general occurrence of the major classes of taxanes across the genus
Taxus
(please note that we only consider species in which at least 25 taxanes have been reported, which eliminates
T. brevifolia
, T. globosa
and T. x
media
from further analysis). 6/8/6-Taxanes and 11(15 → 1) abeo taxanes were detected in all species that have been investigated ( Fig. 3A ). 2(3 → 20) Abeo taxanes were reported to occur in all but three species (not yet reported to be present in
T. brevifolia , T. chinensis
or
T. wallichiana
). Secotaxanes were characterized from
T. canadensis , T. chinensis , T. cuspidata , T. mairei ,
and
T. sumatrana
( Fig. 3A ). Cyclotaxanes were found in samples obtained from
T. baccata , T. canadensis , T. cuspidata
, and
T. yunnanensis
, while diabeotaxanes were isolated from only three species (
T. sumatrana , T. wallichiana
, and
T. yunnanensis
). Taxane classes with a small number of members have generally been reported to occur in fewer species. We believe this to be due to a sampling bias. For example, all known di abeo taxanes were isolated and characterized by three academic groups that focused on
Taxus species
commonly found in Asia. Similarly, the entire body of literature on taxanes from
T. sumatrana
was generated by Ya-Ching Shen’ s team, and the emphasis on these studies was on finding novel structures, not on reporting known ones. The low concentrations of some taxane classes could be another reason for the fact that they have not been detected in a larger number of
Taxus species.
While quantitative information on low abundance taxanes is scarce, the amount of starting material might allow for a rough estimatation: for example, Giovanni Appendino and his team processed 500 kg of
T. baccata
for the characterization of the first cyclotaxane (
, likely indicating a low abundance.

Questions could also be asked about functionalization patterns within a taxane class, which is only meaningful for 6/8/6-taxanes, a class representing roughly 350 different structures (only
Taxus species

with more than 25 reported taxanes will be considered). Too few reports have been published on the occurrence of members of some 6/8/6-taxane subclasses (opened oxetane ring, oxido bridge, taxa-4(20),12- dienes, taxanes with a C-4(5)-double bond). However, 6/8/6-taxane subclasses with a larger number of members (C-5 side chain moieties, C-14 oxygenation, epoxide ring, oxetane ring or both an oxetane ring and a C-13 phenylisoserine side chain) occur in all
Taxus species
( Fig. 3B ).

In summary, we did not find convincing evidence for species-specific patterns of taxane accumulation. The key limitation of such an analysis is, however, the lack of coverage of taxane classes across
Taxus species.
We recognize the challenge of more inclusive analyses, as metabolite patterns are determined not only by genetics (at the species level) but also by environmental conditions, and additional limitations exist for the detection of low abundance constituents in complex matrices (
). Addressing this issue can be considered a grand challenge for the field.

sec.title: 12. Taxane structural diversity as it relates to Taxol biosynthesis
